original_data.question:
A 50-year-old man visits his physician after 20 years of not seeking any medical care. He is concerned about his health after a colleague recently had a heart attack. The patient has no active complaints and says he feels healthy; however, he does not exercise regularly and lives a sedentary lifestyle. He is employed as an administrative position at a local college, and is seated at a desk most of the day. His father had a heart attack at age 54 and his mother is still alive with no health concerns. He does not smoke, only drinks socially, and does not use drugs. Today, his blood pressure is 130/90 mm Hg, pulse is 84/min, and respiratory rate is 14/min. Physical examination reveals an obese male with no significant findings. An ECG shows no abnormalities, and laboratory testing shows the following:
Laboratory test
Serum glucose (fasting)  105 mg/dL
Serum electrolytes 
Sodium  142 mEq/L
Potassium 3.9 mEq/L
Chloride 101 mEq/L
Serum creatinine 0.8 mg/dl
Blood urea nitrogen 10 mg/dl
Cholesterol, total 250 mg/dL
HDL-cholesterol 35 mg/dL
LDL-cholesterol 186 mg/dL
Triglycerides 170 mg/dL
Urinalysis 
Glucose  negative
Ketones negative
Leucocytes negative
Nitrites negative 
Red blood cells (RBC) negative 
Casts negative 
Which of the following lab abnormalities in this patient is an indication for treatment?

model_response:
The patient’s weight is the best indication for treatment. The patient is obese, which puts him at risk for many diseases, including heart disease, diabetes, and hypertension. His blood pressure is only mildly elevated, and may be secondary to his weight. His cholesterol levels are high, but it is unclear if treatment is necessary at this time. His blood glucose level is normal, and there are no signs of infection on urinalysis. The patient should be counseled on diet and exercise, and followed for repeat blood pressure measurements.

###QUERY: 26-Aug-04

###TOPIC: Cardiovascular Diseases

###QUESTION: What is the probability that a patient with aortic regurgitation will develop symptoms?

###Answer: OPTION D IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: The act of going to see some person or place or thing; it can cover a short or long period but refers to a non-permanent arrangement.
Individuals licensed to practice medicine.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
Services obtained from a medical professional for the maintenance of health, prevention of illness, and treatment of illness or injury.
The state of the organism when it functions optimally without evidence of disease.
NECROSIS of the MYOCARDIUM caused by an obstruction of the blood supply to the heart (CORONARY CIRCULATION).
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
A response indicating that an individual feels or felt healthy.

Physical activity which is usually regular and done with the intention of improving or maintaining PHYSICAL FITNESS or HEALTH. Contrast with PHYSICAL EXERTION which is concerned largely with the physiologic and metabolic response to energy expenditure.
A type of lifestyle that lacks physical exercise, characterized by sitting, reading, watching television or using a computer for much of the day without vigorous physical exertion.
A reference to the alignment of an object, a particular situation or view of a situation, or the location of an object.
An institution of higher education created to educate and grant degrees; often a part of a university.
The state or act of one who sits; the posture of one who occupies a seat.
Occurring or done each day.
Male parents, human or animal.
NECROSIS of the MYOCARDIUM caused by an obstruction of the blood supply to the heart (CORONARY CIRCULATION).
How long something has existed; elapsed time since birth.
Female parents, human or animal.
Visible gaseous suspension of carbon and other particulate matter emitted from burning substances.
A single serving of a beverage; any liquid suitable for drinking.
Relating to human society and its members.
Drugs intended for human or veterinary use, presented in their finished dosage form. Included here are materials used in the preparation and/or formulation of the finished dosage form.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.
The rate of breathing (inhalation and exhalation) measured within in a unit time, usually expressed as breaths per minute.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.

A status with BODY WEIGHT that is grossly above the recommended standards, usually due to accumulation of excess FATS in the body. The standards may vary with age, sex, genetic or cultural background. In the BODY MASS INDEX, a BMI greater than 30.0 kg/m2 is considered obese, and a BMI greater than 40.0 kg/m2 is considered morbidly obese (MORBID OBESITY).
A person who belongs to the sex that normally produces sperm. The term is used to indicate biological sex distinctions, cultural gender role distinctions, or both.
A study that evaluates the effect of a treatment on cardiac electrical activity, as assessed by electrocardiography.
Any procedure that involves testing or manipulating a sample of blood, urine, or other body substance in a laboratory setting.
Abstaining from FOOD.

An element in the alkali group of metals with an atomic symbol K, atomic number 19, and atomic weight 39.10. It is the chief cation in the intracellular fluid of muscle and other cells. Potassium ion is a strong electrolyte that plays a significant role in the regulation of fluid volume and maintenance of the WATER-ELECTROLYTE BALANCE.
A quantitative measurement of the amount of creatinine present in a sample of serum.

An absence finding of the specified component / analyte, organism or clinical sign based on the established threshold of the performed test or procedure.

\[Note: Negative does not necessarily imply the complete absence of the specified item.\]
Red blood cells. Mature erythrocytes are non-nucleated, biconcave disks containing HEMOGLOBIN whose function is to transport OXYGEN.

An absence finding of the specified component / analyte, organism or clinical sign based on the established threshold of the performed test or procedure.

\[Note: Negative does not necessarily imply the complete absence of the specified item.\]
Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
An explanation of the cause of some phenomenon or action.

Used with diseases for therapeutic interventions except drug therapy, diet therapy, radiotherapy, and surgery, for which specific subheadings exist. The concept is also used for articles and books dealing with multiple therapies.
